Everyone watches as the speech continues. The BARTENDER reaches for a bottle of the oldest scotch on the shelf an starts to pour tall drinks without comment. A SMOKER reaches into his pocket and takes out a full pack of cigarettes. He blithely holds it open and EVERYONE at the bar reaches for one.
The President walks to a large monitor on stage with him. Projected on the TV, we see a NASA film about the comet.
Comets begin far out in space. They're what's left over from the creation of the solar system after the planets were formed, billions of years ago. (MORE) (CONTINUED )
These chunks of space debris are in an orbit around the sun, very much like our own, but every now and then; one of them is bumped, a bit like a billiard ball (MORE) (CONTINUED )
on a pool table, and it gets knocked into a new orbit.
People are screaming on the phones. A few are in shock, still watching the set, Bobby's one of them.

We've got stand-ups on line; Beijing, Rome, San Paulo, Cairo, Berlin... (yelling out) Anybody know how big the one was that wiped out the dinosaurs! A musician sets up a portable keyboard to begin composing Worth frantically gives him instructions.

Something majestic, mysterious, with a fanfare for intros and a theme for longer promos The CAMERA finds Stuart and Ira hunched over a computer monitor with a graphic artist working on a comet graphic.
It's hitting the goddamn earth!
That's what he's saying!
It'll scare the shit outta everybody!
The streets are alive with people, people pouring outside some with binoculars and long lenses on their cameras, everyone looking up, to see the comet.

Now, if the comet passes around the sun and were to hold to it's present course, then sometime on August 16, 2000 there's a chance we might have an impact. Jenny's sitting there with her notebook, what's she going to say when the time comes? (CONTINUED )

So for the past eight months, the United States and Russia have been building the largest spaceship ever constructed; it's being built in orbit around the earth. We call it the Messiah. I want to emphasize that some scientists argued that there was no reason to spend the time and money to intercept something that probably won't hit us, but we decided not to take that risk. And right now, a team of American astronauts, and one Russian, are at Cape Canaveral in Florida. In two months they will leave on the Shuttle to board the Messiah; this is the crew that will stop the comet.
Five men and one woman in new flight suits.
I'd like the world to meet some extraordinary people. First is Mission Commander Oren Monash. Commander, would you introduce us to your Team?

It'd be an honor, sir. Executive Officer Andrea Baker, Navigator Mark Simon, Medical Officer Gus Partenza, from Russia, Nuclear Specialist Colonel Mikhail Tulchinsky, and Rendezvous Pilot Spurgeon Tanner. BAKER has the relaxed confidence of a woman who has never failed at anything. SIMON is black, military. TULCHINSKY, being Russian, shows his life on his face, every woman, every smile, every heart-break.
Hello, Mr. President.
Captain Tanner, you flew six Shuttle Missions and were the last man to walk on the moon, weren't you sir? (CONTINUED )

Yes, sir. But Oren will be doing most of the flying on this one. I'll just be taking us down to the comet surface. Monash is smiling for the camera, but something's going o behind his eyes. Jealousy? Pride? Frustration? (CONTINUED )

It's good to know we're going to have your kind of experience up there. Godspeed to you all. We're counting on you. The cameras' red lights go dark at the Cape. The astronau drop their public personas, pull off their mikes.
Goddamn dog and pony show. Monash shoots a look to Tanner, starts off.
Are we having a problem, son?
...No problem... But he doesn't look back. Tanner watches him go.
Beck's back at his podium.

I want to let the children know that you're going to hear a lot of people worrying about this. Some of your Moms and Dads, grandparents, even your big brothers and sisters... well, they might be scared. So I'm telling you to tell them, everything is going to be okay. I promise.
The big TV screen, the President. People pour out of the Cineplex to watch as the word spreads.
Beck drops the smile he'd used for the kids, looks direct into CAMERA, suddenly hard, tough.

Now I want to talk to the grownups. We know that the threat of an apocalypse is going to give some people an excuse for lawlessness. As of this evening, I've placed the National Guard and the Army on full alert. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

We will not tolerate any disruption of our way of life. Our society will continue as normal. Work will go on. You will pay your bills. As the CAMERA moves in slowly on Beck, Jenny shifts in he seat, preparing for the biggest moment of her life.

There will be no hoarding. There will be no sudden profiteering. I am freezing all wages, all prices. I have instructed the Secretary of the Treasury to close the nation's financial markets. All stock bond, interest and commodity rates, all currency exchange rates and precious metal prices will remain fixed at today's prices. What a bottle of water cost you yesterday, it will cost you tomorrow. Anyone selling something for more than it cost this morning will be arrested. Anyone rioting, anyone looting, anyone.., well, that person is going to be shot on sight. (let's it sink in) Now I'll take a few questions. All hands shoot up in the air, questions are shouted. The sound of Nikon MOTORS and SHUTTERS is like jungle noise i a Tarzan movie. Jenny tries to be heard, but she's a novice, buried by the regulars.
Ms. Lerner? who? The press room regulars look around. Jenny. It's her moment in the sun, she stands.. Man, is she nervous.
Jenny Lerner, MSNBC. Mr. President, why wasn't the announcement made sooner?
Chaos reigns, anchors move into place, ready themselves for when the press conference ends. But Stuart's head has snapped around to stare at the screen, his mouth open.
Jenny Lerner?
Son of a bitch... (CONTINUED )
But Eric and Bobby are grinning in back, loving it.

Until we knew that a rocket could be built and the comet intercepted, there was no reason to alarm the planet. Beth's staring at the back of Jenny's head, if she had an ice pick she'd bury it in her scrawny skull. Everyone raises their hands for the next question, yelling.
You have another question, Ms. Lerner? She didn't really. She fumbles nervously. The press corp' near mutiny, the fix is in and they know it.

Robin and her STAFF, putting their magazine together, watching Jenny on TV as she asks a question. Some look from Robin to the set and back, as she is comprehending that her daughter has just moved up in the world.
Is there a connection between the comet and the recall of American troops from abroad? Beck's not happy with that question.

Our fighting men and women are coming home because we felt it prudent in light of domestic security concerns, to have them available, although I certainly hope we don't need to use them. (looks for next question) Joy and Robin share a smile, her mother's daughter.
Jason and Chloe watch Jenny on TV.
Mr. President! Sir! One final question! Now they understand why she was behaving so strangely at the bar.  61
Beck smiles, points to her again. Now it's not only Beth, the entire Press Corp's sharpening their long knives.

MSNBC has learned that Secretary Rittenhouse did not leave for the reasons your administration announced. Isn't it true sir, that not everyone in your administration is convinced that the Messiah will save us? Beck gives Jenny a hard look.

Secretary Rittenhouse served this country with full devotion, and resigned for personal reasons. We have more important things before us than to consider the petty soap opera of Washington. I promise you, Ms. Lerner, and all of you, those in this room and those hearing my voice, that all of us, at some point in the next eight months, will entertain our worst fears and concerns. But I promise you, life will go on. We shall prevail. There will be no Armageddon! The questions erupt again. Beck nods to Jenny, she smiles sits. This part of their deal concluded.
(pointing) David.
Exactly when and how was the comet discovered?

Two scientists searching the skies found the comet and while racing from their observatory to alert the world, were killed in a car crash. That was thirteen months ago. It took another five months for their papers to be discovered. The questions erupt again. (CONTINUED )
Sally?
Sir, what's the comet's name?
Since Marcus Wolf and his colleague Leo Biederman discovered the comet we named it for them: Wolf- Biederman.
Leo and his family watch in their suburban living room. His father, DON. Mother, ELLEN. Little sister, JANE.
Leo Biederman? They watch in shock. Their phone begins to RING.
He means you doesn't he?
How much notice did you give other world leaders? (CONTINUED )
Shhh... I'm trying to listen!

Our ambassadors were given briefing papers this afternoon, and instructed to convey them to their host countries. The Russians, with their expertise in nuclear propulsion systems, were told last year. Now the DOORBELL joins the phone that's still RINGING. Jane looks at all the grown-ups not answering either, confused. Hops off the couch, heads for the front door. On the TV, President Beck concludes the questioning.
Thank you all. Beck steps back from the podium, heads for the door as reporters continue to SHOUT questions. Six year old Jane stands beside Leo.
The front door's for you. Leo turns away from the set, walks to the still open fron door, still in shock. It's Sarah, breathless. Excited.
I'm not dead.
Dr. Wolf? From astronomy club?
I think maybe so. Leo looks past her to the residential street and a crowd outside. The Hotchners are on the lawn behind Sarah.
I think it's neat. Nobody on our block ever discovered the world was going to end before.
It's not going to end.
Well it's still really neat.

It's clearing out, fast. TV rushing to stand-ups. Print phoning copy desks. Jenny stands, still at her place in the second row of the now almost empty room. Savoring it, this moment, everything she's worked for. Turns. Beth's there. Doesn't say anything. Turns, and walks away. Leaving Jenny alone. Jenny wants to feel ashamed, or guilty. But she doesn't. She's where she's always wanted to be.
Everyone is cheering and clapping for Leo on stage. Mr. Perry's there moderating. Leo's parents. The local press is in full force. Sarah's with her girlfriends.

It was really just luck, I guess, that I found it. Anyone could have. As far as we know, what happened was that Dr. Wolf saw the comet in my photograph so he shared the discovery with me. Then he was killed in that crash and everything got mixed up in Washington so the President thought I was dead too.
How does it make you feel having your name on it? (CONTINUED )

Well, I don't want anyone to think that I'm trying to take something away from Dr. Wolf, because, you know... I'm not. One of Sarah's friends nudges her, shows her a Newsweek: Leo on the cover with his telescope.
Are you sorry you found it?
No. If I hadn't taken that picture of the comet, and it hadn't gone to Dr. Wolf at the observatory, who knows what would have happened? Sarah leans forward, calls out a question.
Are you scared?
I have a history test tomorrow. I'm scared of that. Appreciative laughter and applause from the student audie and the press. Another kid, a smartass showing off.
You know you're going to have sex a lot more now than anyone else in our class. That gets a chorus of adolescent HOOTS and APPLAUSE.
Really? Perry intercedes good-naturedly.
Thanks for your sexual insight Mr. Thurman, you can sit down now. But all the attention only spurs the kid on.

Famous people always get sex, Mr. Perry. That's one of the main reasons it's good to be famous. More applause, Perry smiles, Harold takes a bow to his adoring peers. Leo sneaks a look out to Sarah. She's smiling back. All this talk about sex. Her friends notice, grin. Sarah notices them noticing.  68
Simon, Tulchinsky, Monash, Baker, and Partenza are sittin at a table in a crowded military bar. The juke box is playing. The Astronauts are deep in a somewhat drunken huddle. Monash is upset.
Frank Gifford was a great football player, but I'd bust his ass if he played against me now.
I wish I'd been to the moon, I respect everyone who went there, but this isn't the moon.
All of his training was for a stable surface, the moon didn't have two pound dust particles ejecting at three hundred feet a second.
This isn't about ego.
Of course it is, it's all about ego... but sometimes the ego is right. '
And dust particles...

(drunker than the others) The moon, the moon, the moon wasn't spinning when he landed on it, the moon didn't have a fourteen hour rotay... Rotational period, seven hours of sun, seven hours of darkness, it was light all the time when he landed on the moon. He could see. We're not going to be able to see.
You can't see now anyway.
Don't worry... (in Russian) We can do it.
What?  44A.
We can do it. And then we hear a familiar Voice.

I woke up this morning and I realized that none of you want me here. You don't even really know who I am. I walked on the moon, but I didn't belong to you. I belonged to your Daddies. Now, if I ask you to ask your Daddies what I meant to them, to explain to you what I'm doing here, that's only going to make things worse. So what do we do?  44B-46.
You haven't trained for this mission. We respect you...
I appreciate that...
But you're here...you're here because the powers that be think we need someone familiar on the trip. You're here for public relations.
I'm here because the powers that be know that I am the only one on this mission who has ever landed on the moon and I have five hundred landings on aircraft carriers...
We've trained...
On flight simulators. And this is not a video game, son.

Leo's little sister JANE changes the channel on the TV. O every station there's a comet graphic, some in the manner Chuck Jones, others are Soviet Realism, Moebius, computer enhanced photos of the real thing. This is all that anyon is watching or talking about. She lands on a documentary.
Fifty thousand years ago, a 300,000 ton meteor landed here in Arizona.
I want Xena! Where's Xena? The phone's RINGING. Ellen answers it.  69 47.

Jane, please, it's not The Tunguska River, Siberia, on anymore, in 1908, trees fell for 30 (into phone) miles... A railroad engineer No... I don't think 300 miles away had to stop so, he really can't. his train because the tracks were shaking, and were hot DON BIEDERMAN to the touch. All of this Who is it? caused by a meteor only two hundred feet wide.
Primetime Live again. Jane changes channels to find POLITICALLY INCORRECT.
Is the sky really falling? Do we really think the world is coming to an end? And how can we trust Russian nuclear rockets when the Russians can't figure out how to get phones to work in Moscow?

I love the comet! I want to die! I want everyone to die! You know how you hate it when you leave the room and you know everyone is going to talk about you? That's one problem that the comet's going to take care of!
I think they only say lovely things about me. GOLDTHWAITE. Leave the room. Changes channels again. LETTERMAN.
A drum roll. So here it is, tonight's top ten list: the ten things you'll miss least when the world ends. Ten, Broccoli. Nine, Iraq. Eight, commercials for Grey Poupon... And again:
The Messiah Mission, too little too late? Not all scientists agree with NASA's plan for destroying the comet. (MORE)
Joining us tonight are Morton Entrekin, from FEMA, and from The University of Arizona's Interplanetary Sciences Department Dr.s Gene and Carolyn Shoemaker --
Sarah and her folks watch, Vicky now pregnant.
Mr. Entrekin, the Shoemaker's have been critical of the science suggesting that this mission is feasible or necessary. During this Sarah gets up and walks to the front door.
Where are you going? Every scientific endeavor has risks Gene.

Out front. GENE (ON TV) The margin of error on the CHUCK HOTCHNER comet's trajectory suggests It's midnight. that it could easily miss us by a tenth of an SARAH astronomical unit, that's I don't think there's ten million miles. anyone in the world who isn't watching ENTREKIN (ON TV) television. I want to Are you suggesting we just be the only one who's wait and pray? outside.
The comet is traveling at a hundred thousand miles an hour. The Messiah has to catch up, hold onto it, set the bombs, and get off. We've never attempted anything remotely this complex in space.
Sarah comes out of her house. The street is deserted, TVs dance in every living room window. A SOUND. Wheels on pavement. Leo rollerblades across the street under the streetlight.
Hi... Leo stops, smiles. Watches her approach.
You're not watching TV?
They just keep saying the same things. She stares above her at the stars.
It looks so peaceful. A beat as he joins her staring at the night sky.
The only reason I joined astronomy club was because of you. (CONTINUED )
Really?
You liked the stars and I figured if you liked them they must be worth looking at.
That's so nice. This is too close for them, too emotional.
We got invited to the White House.
Of course. You're an important person now.
We're going to see the launch with the President. My whole family.
That's so neat.
Yeah. She smiles, he can be very disarming.
You've changed.
No, I haven't.
Your braces.
(he grins, no braces) I got them off today. They don't know what to say. Look up again to the stars.

head_text.subj: MINUTES. IMPACT 13 MONTHS 7 DAYS, 10 HOURS, 46 MINUTES.

text: A pleasant house near Houston. The backyard is filled with about FORTY PEOPLE, THE ASTRONAUTS, THEIR FAMILY, including their PARENTS and their CHILDREN. (CONTINUED)

Running around are TEN OR TWELVE CHILDREN. The CAMERA tracks through the cluster of people, and we hear packets of conversation. The mood, fueled by beer an chips, is happy. Music plays in the backyard speakers. MIKHAIL TULCHINSKY is with TWO VERY PRETTY WOMEN.
A nuclear reactor in space? Isn't that dangerous?
No, no, no. This is all Russian design, Russian science, the same people who designed Chernobyl. He waits for the response he wanted, horror.
Well, Chernobyl almost worked. And the camera goes to: SIMON and his fiancee, WENDY. She's showing off her diamond ring to another GROUP OF WIVES AND FRIENDS.
Wendy, I'm going to marry you, but the day we get back I can't just go to the church.

The church will come to you, Simon. You're all invited. The camera finds GUS PARTENZA, with ANDREA BAKER, and her husband, DAVID, and their toddlers, BRITTANY and ALICIA. David holds the squirming Brittany.
What happens when you set off the bombs? Baker tries to answer, but Brittany squirms away. (CONTINUED )
Partenza a 49B.
Well, as, long as we plant the bombs... We have seven hours... Brittany! Brittany, come back here... As long as we plant the bombs and... Brittany... nswers for her.
We have seven hours to plant the bombs and get off the surface before the sun heats it up. (CONTINUED )

We leave them and find Monash and his wife MARIETTE. He is seated, she is standing and he is talking to the Baby in her very large belly. As he narrates, he follows the curvature of her belly to her breasts.
Oren Junior! Here are your orders: upon your first entering into earth's atmosphere, proceed directly along the exterior of the mothership to the twin storage tanks for refueling.
He's not a rocket-ship... he's a Baby, Oren, your Baby, our Baby.
I know. They kiss. Brittany, free again, runs past us leading the camera to Tanner, talking to his two grown sons, DWIGHT a STEVE. They're both in uniform.

When my father went to war in 1942, he didn't see me or your grandmother for three years. I was eight when he left. You boys were what, four and six when I went to the moon? (they nod) You saw me go into space seven times, didn't you?
Yessir...
And I came back every time, didn't
(MORE)

(they nod) Your mother and I used to play a game when she was still alive. The game was, if there was a chance I might not be coming back, she wouldn't say it, and I wouldn't say it. But this time, I want to say it to you.
(a beat) This time I probably won't be coming back. You know that?
(quietly) ...Yessir... The three men stare at each other. Don't see Mitch Hefter come up behind them.
Another beer?
Thanks. You remember my boys don't you, Mitch?
(handshakes all around) Sure I do... A LITTLE GIRL SNAPS their picture.- Tanner smiles, wraps an arm around his two boys.
What'd you think of the crew?
Heroes all. The finest group I've ever had the privilege of serving with.
Off the record. Tanner looks to his sons, then:
They've been trained in ways I'll never understand.: They're smarter and in better shape than we ever were in the old days. They're sober, they're serious. (MORE) (CONTINUED )
(looks to his sons) I guess I'd be a little happier about this whole thing if I thought that any of them were as scared as I am.
They're not afraid of dying, they're afraid of screwing up on TV. Two CATERERS wheel out an immense cake in the shape of th earth. People APPLAUD, the children are dazzled.

Fish, would you do the honor? We see that Monash is uncomfortable with Tanner getting the spotlight. Mariette settles him. Tanner raises the knife to the cake. A few people with cameras are ready to snap the picture. He hesitates. Hefter motions with his hand: Cut the cake. Tanner raises the knife. He can't.
Is this supposed to be a joke? Cutting up the earth, is that supposed to give us good luck?

Fish, do it for the kids. We see how desperately the children want the cake. They'v surrounded Tanner. Everyone is watching him. He takes the knife and uses it like a trowel, smearing the icing until everything is a swirl. He looks to the children.
You know what this is? A Kid shakes his head, no, very soberly.

It's the comet. And what do we do to comets? He plunges a hand into the comet, and the children do the same, laughing. Hefter gives him a look, and the Astronau are unhappy with his sudden mania. Tanner sees the earth destroyed, the coast lines wrecked.
(CONTINUED )

head_text.subj: MINUTE. IMPACT 12 MONTHS, 9 DAYS, 12 HOURS, 35 MINUTES.

text: The President, Entrekin, aides, Leo, and the Biedermans, watch the Shuttle launch on TV. Jenny's on a stand-up in front of a large NASA wall mural.
We're now only minutes away from the launch of the Shuttle Atlantis (MORE) (CONTINUED )
and the beginning of the historic Messiah Mission...
Okay, all flight controllers, we're at T minus 3 minutes and counting... give it a close look.
APU's look good, LOX and LH2 are pressurized. A shot of the Atlantis on its pad. The President makes his way to a glass jar of M&Ms and grabs a handful.
Who's voice are we hearing now, Jenny?
Tim, that's Flight Director Mitch Hefter, former Gemini and Apollo astronaut... Leo tries to concentrate on the TV but can't help staring at his surroundings, the Presidential Seal, the desk.
Who's your book agent, Leo?
Sir?
You're writing a book about this aren't you?
(not sure where the leader of the Free World and the Commander in Chief is going) I have a book report due on Tuesday.
So you're not going to write a book?
I don't know.
What kind of American are you? You're famous and you don't want to get rich from it? You'll kill the economy. (CONTINUED )
I'm issuing an executive order, Leo; when the President makes a bad joke, would you laugh?
(smiling) Yessir.
(referring to M&M's) Green?
Blue.
Everything's is going to be okay, you know that, don't you?
Yessir.
Thank you. (the countdown is past ten) Here we go.
Flight, we're go for autosequence.
Good luck and Godspeed, Atlantis.

. Three... Two... One... Liftoff! The Shuttle lifts off the pad in a burst of painfully hot light. The big ship ROARS above, tearing into the night sky. Everyone in the room watches, and then applauds. The President puts his hands on Leo's shoulders.
(CONTINUED )
Well, and what are you doing here?
I've been busy, and I haven't been paying attention to you.
I've been busy, too. This is the last issue of the magazine...
No!

(lightly mocking Jenny's shock) Yes! The advertisers are calling, up and canceling. Why would anyone support a magazine devoted to old, expensive, beautiful things when all the attractive young women are on television spreading panic?
That's not fair! The news is good, the mission is going to succeed.
I stopped watching the news. Does anything I do have any effect on anything that happens in space?
I mean... but... the whole world is watching.

The whole world minus one. For years I've always been a little ashamed of what I do, worrying all day about whether this piece of furniture is real or a fake, or whether that painting is better than this painting. No, now that no one has the time to buy antiques, old, beautiful things, it Means that I actually have a sacred purpose. It's like the Russians who saved the old palaces when the Germans were coming; they didn't have time to cart everything away, so they chopped out a bit of the floor and cut away a few feet of (MORE) (CONTINUED )

curtain, and when the war was over they built everything back from the pieces. I'm saving the pieces now, keeping a record. If the comet does hit, and they want to know what the world looked like, they'll be looking at the work I'm doing today.
Mother, listen to me! The comet is going to be turned away and everyone is going to be so relieved that they'll spend money like the world really is coming to an end.
That's pretty to think so.  83 56.

You're right on the numbers, Atlantis. On the monitors, a huge docking device fills the view. But Tanner's not watching, he's staring out the side at something they're passing but we can't see. Whistles softly.
...Jesus, that's big... Partenza and Tulchinsky follow his gaze.
Whoa...no shit...
Contact in three meters ...two...one... (a little nudge) We're here. (CONTINUED )
Well done, Atlantis... Monash turns around, grins.
Wow. Tanner still staring out the porthole.
...Sweet mother of God.
WE PULL AWAY from Tanner in the window, out past the Shuttle, past the spindly, solar to find --
panel arms of the Station Docked and tethered to the Space Station. It's massive, a 747 next to the Shuttle's Cessna. putting the finishing touches on
Workers float in space, its assembly. (CONTINUED )
Tulchinsky is in the cargo hold, checking the loaded nuke in zero gravity.: Monash is on the intercom.
How we doing, Mikhail?
Nukes prepped and stowed.

Let's get moving. Tulchinsky grabs a handhold, pulls himself along the carg compartment, through the hatch into the living quarters. Past the toilet, shower, galley. Pulls himself into the aft compartment. It's tight but functional, conduit, switching panels, bundles containing thousands of wires. Monash is up front with Baker and Simon. Tanner buckling up in back, Tulchinsky sets himself down with Partenza in front of a complex set of monitors and oscillators that bank up to the ceiling.
Nervous? (CONTINUED )
Just not used to the back seat.
It's not so bad. View stinks. Monash turns in his seat, looks back at Tulchinsky.
Colonel, let's see what this baby can do. Tulchinsky grins. Punches commands into his keyboard.
Hope you're right about this thing working, Mikhail.
Just between you and me...
Oh, shit...
Orion burn in ten...nine...eight... The rapidly moving pattern on the oscillator gets closer and closer to a straight line.
Hold onto your hats, boys and girls.
It's not my hat I'm worried about.

The nuclear reaction EXPLODES against the backplate, lighting up the darkness with a tremendous, BLINDING puls The Messiah takes off like a bat out of hell, CATAPULTED out into space. Disappears among the stars.
Snow on the ground. Leo and Sarah look through his telescope. IN HIS EYEPIECE, the Orion pulses.
There it is! He steps back so she can look. She looks.
It's beautiful Leo... (CONTINUED )
Now she takes his hand. Still looking.
What if it doesn't work? What if the world ends?
The world is not going to end.
(delights in tormenting her) It could, it could, let's just say the comet hits... how do you not want to die? —
You are morbid.
Think about it, maybe the comet is a great way to die. No time to think, squished like a bug. I'd rather die like that than by drowning.
Leo!
And even if it doesn't hit us on the head, even if it lands somewhere else, the heat from the comet as it passes through the atmosphere burns up all the forests in the world.

I don't want to talk about this, Leo. It makes me sad. It makes me think about all the things I'll never get a chance to do... Shakespeare in London and ... hiking in Colorado and... even... Disneyworld, just a nice time with my Mom and Dad and... and love. I'll never get any of that now. So just shut up.
I'm sorry.
It's not your fault. (MORE) (CONTINUED )
We're too young. It's all wrong now, because I don't have time for you to figure things out, I don't have three years for you to wake up and know what you feel about me.
What do you mean?
That's just it, you have to ask. Because you're still just a little kid, part of you. And if the world is coming to an end, we don't have time for that.
what?
(exasperated) You love me and I love you And she runs away from him.
Tulchinsky, Baker and Partenza load aluminum encased bomb into the MOLES, already mounted on the SLED. Metal, wires radioactive warnings. It's demanding work with no gravity
How's it coming? (CONTINUED )
Inserting the last nuke now. When it CLICKS in place, the digital readout BLINKS ALIVE
Stuart leads the staff meeting. Ira, Worth, Marianne Beth, Tim, Jenny. Jenny sits at the grown-up table, quiet lost in her own thoughts.
Beth, White House reactions. Marianne, all the world watching. We have enough satellite space?
Seventy-eight up-links.
Tim, Mission Control in Houston. (Tim looks up, surprised) Ira, the science guys lined up?
If they've got a PhD, we own them.
This is the most important story of our lives. Let's not fuck it up. The end of the meeting, people start out. Jenny looks up.
...Stuart? What about me? People stop, is she finally going to get her comeuppance?
You're on the anchor desk and don't you ever hold back a story for two days.
I'm sorry but, the President...

The hell with the President. He has no right making deals with a reporter who has no authority to accept his terms. I probably would have held the story, but that would have been my decision and not yours. And I would have protected you. It was your scoop. You own the story. Don't do that again. (CONTINUED )
Thank you, Stuart.
Yeah. Okay.  63.
Monash lines the Messiah up with the tail of the comet, following a computer path in the cockpit.

Son of a bitch doesn't know what he's doing.

...we've landed...

Oh, thank god...
Tanner and Baker work. Locking in computer coordinates.
Depressurizing bay.
Opening payload doors. Don't let that little bit of gravity down there go to your heads.

Looks like all you did was dent a fender, Fish. Dad's gonna be mad when we get home. The comet is mostly very old terrain, worn smooth by eons of travel, hilly in places, craters. All sizes of rocks float past them, have to be batted away. The weather is made even stranger by the frequent gas lightning above. Ooh, look at that baby dig.
Fish, tell the guys at JSC their mole works like a charm.
Like butter baby.
Go get ‘em, boy.

Dammit...

136 137 138 On Simon's helmet cam we see Monash look up.
How long's that going to take?

An hour? (dry WASP) An hour? Darling, that gives me no time at all to go home, get dressed and be at the theater on time for the curtain. What were we thinking when we made these reservations? Tanner and Baker look at the clock. 1:49:47...:46...

text: Monitors, a few sofas, very governmental. The families of the astronauts watch MSNBC, hold each other’s hands. MSNB has added a sunrise clock on screen, not very comforting. Jenny's on camera, interviewing Dr. Van Sertma.
What happens if they don't get off of the surface in time?

The sun striking the comet will cause the temperature to rise three hundred and fifty degrees in only a few minutes and activate the high speed gas jets. If that happens it'll be like trying to work ina mine field.
Monash and Simon angle the sled to the final location.
We're on Target Two, Messiah.
Partenza and Tulchinsky drill at Target One. A trail of debris rises out of the hole, shoved up by the MOLE.
How's our time?  71A.
Getting tight. 36:30. (CONTINUED )
It's taking too long.
Simon and Monash Work above their final MOLE hole. Feed out the control line, read the digital depth LED.
MOLE 4 running true, at 26 meters.
Son of a bitch...
what?
It's stuck.
Monash looks down the hole. All he can see is debris.
Try backing it up.
Tanner and Baker watch all this on the helmet cams.
What's your depth?
Sixteen meters.
That enough?
No, it'll just blow pieces off the surface.
That's not deep enough.
No shit, thanks for the insight. Blow three pitons, back the sled off.
Simon releases all but one piton, shoves the sled away.  73.

Mole three at depth. Coming your way. Simon screws a pitch into the surface, attaches a line to hold him in place. Monash is using the MOLE control line as a tether, they're stirring up carbon as they work.
I'm going in.
The hole?!
See if I can free it up. Monash goes in feet first, using the line as a rope.
They watch Monash's helmet cam as he descends into the hole. Like dropping into a small well, his helmet lights illuminate the dark, veiny walls close around him.
How's my time?
Another six minutes and they won't have time to get back to us. A beat. Tanner leaps for the pilot's seat.
Blow the tethers. She realizes what he's thinking.
We go get them and we may not have enough fuel to get back off the surface.
Blow the goddamn tethers!
Calculate exactly how much prop we need to get off this rock! Shut us down when we hit it. She TYPES into a keyboard. Numbers rush by.
Got it!
74 A BEEP. The aft thrusters ignite and the ship moves away fast.
Tulchinsky and Partenza arrive. Monash works his way down to the top of the MOLE. Braces himself against the walls, gets his feet on it.
Give it some juice. The MOLE shimmies a little, shakes, but doesn't move.
Hold up. It stops, Monash rocks it back and forth with his boots.
Try backing it up again.
Baker's computer BEEPS.
That's it.
Little more, little more... She looks at the fuel usage whizzing by. (CONTINUED )
Shut it down!

We have a visual? Across the valley. The yellow sled.
Straight ahead one hundred yards.
Monash kicks and shakes the MOLE, tugs up on the feed lin
...Come on... you bastard. Time?
11:04. Figured we'd better pick you kids up after school. Check your six...100 yards.
Partenza looks, sees the Messiah hovering in the distance Notices the sun striking the hilltops on the other side o the valley. Checks over his shoulder at the coming dawn.
I think we'd better hurry, boys.
One more time, Mark.
The MOLE struggles, RUMBLES and then...begins to DIG.
It's going!
Baker stares at the dawn horizon.
I don't think they've got 10 minutes. The sun is rising between two mountains, it's going to pour straight down into the valley, right where they are.  155 156 157 158 159 76.
Debris is shooting up from the hole.
MOLE’s at forty-two meters.
Sun's rising behind you, coming up fast. Partenza sees the rapidly shrinking shadows. They move much faster than earth. Everywhere it strikes, the surfac gets unstable. Rocks fly, jets explode.
Face shields down! The three men on the surface down their gold shields.
Monash is pummeled with debris shooting up from the diggi MOLE. Pulling himself up the control line as fast as he can. No way he has time for his face shield in this mess.
The sun marches closer and closer. Now only thirty yards away, jets explode like mortars in the heat.
MOLE's at depth and armed!
Tanner and Baker watch the sun's approach with alarm.
Get the hell out of there!
Partenza screams back into his headset.
Oren's still in the hole! Simon stares into the hole, sees the top of Monash's helm
Another three meters!
Oh, Christ... The sun is only yards away. (CONTINUED )
Oren, come on, go...go...!
Monash grabs the line. Pulls hard, propelling himself up much too fast, like a missile. Shooting out onto the --

Heading straight up into orbit. Partenza grabs his passin boot and is pulled along until Partenza's tether catches. They bob in space, the light gravity slowly bringing them back down. Monash staring out in shock.
Get us down! Simon grabs the tether line, pulls them back, spinning them slowly as they come. Partenza looks up, realizes.
Oren, your face shield! Monash looks down, what? Just as his face rotates full into the blinding sun. Screams in pain.

Ahhhhhh...AAHHHH... 1!!! Monash claws at the helmet, trying to get to his blinded eyes. They get him back to the surface, SLAM his shield DOWN, drag him behind them to the sled. The sun hits them as they FLOP Monash on top, lash him down. The ground begins to boil and steam.
My eyes...oh god...my eyes...
Gus, come on! Come on...! It's only yards around the sled to Partenza's seat but th sunblasted surface is cracking, EXPLODING. He's trying to cross a jet minefield.
Get out of there! Partenza dodges one, sees a clear spot, steps and BOOM! A jet explodes into his chest. Rocketing him up like a huma cannonball.
Gus...Gus...! Partenza's sling-shot out into space hundreds of feet.  162
we're losing one! Tanner leaps to look. Partenza's helmet cam has a quickly diminishing view of the comet below.
He's got escape velocity. A thousand feet and climbing.
He watches the comet recede.
They're looking up, frozen. Jets EXPLODING all around.

The sun works its way across the valley, closer and close to the Messiah.

head_text.subj: IN THE SMALL ROOM AT JSC 165

text: The families stare at the TV, in shook. Hold each other. The sun clock now blinks 0:00 on the screen.
Jenny and the MSNBC staff watch the Messiah pictures.
Tulchinsky helps load the GROANING Monash onto a hoist.
Retract hoist one! Monash is pulled up into the Cargo bay. The sun now fully striking the Messiah. Rocks and jets shoot all over the place. Tulchinsky SNAPS onto another hoist. (CONTINUED )
Retract four! Tulchinsky starts up. Simon connects himself. (CONTINUED )
Retract two! The hoist starts and BOOM! A rock SLAMS into Simon's forearm, hard. Sends him swinging like a kid on a rope over a river SLAMMING into the underbelly.
The hull vibrates from the rocks like POPPING corn.
Firing primary thrusters.
Payload doors are still open!
Close them as we go!
Is Oren with you, Simon? Is Oren on the ship?
We're going now!
The ship fires its thrusters. Lifts up, the men still dangling below.
It's choppy. Rocks BANG. Tanner steers as best he can.
The ship flies off.
The three men are being reeled in through the now closing doors. A final rock EXPLODES up through the doors, SHATTE a light. Tulchinsky releases himself, swings Monash over safety.
I think my arm's broken... Tulchinsky reels Simon in. Releases him.  T9A.
Repressurize the cargo bay.
Cargo bay repressurized. Tulchinsky comes in out of his EVA suit.
We have to go get Gus.
There's not enough time.
He's going to die out there! Something SLAMS into the underbelly, sends them careening off to the left as Tanner wrestles the stick. (CONTINUED )
We can still find him, he has a beacon!
I don't have time to argue with you. Sit down and shut-up. The ship BUCKS and SLAMS through debris.
Turn it on! Turn on the fucking locator!
We barely have enough propellant to get out of the coma!
We can't just leave him. We have to go back.
If we go for Gus, we all die...!
Monash hears this.
We can't just leave him in space.
Tulchinsky, listen to Tanner. It's his ship now.
Tulchinsky slowly lowers himself into a seat. Leans his head back, exhausted, tears run down his face.
It's very quiet on the set. Finally, Jenny:
This has been such an indescribable day, hasn't it? Where do you begin? The Messiah has lifted safely off the comet, and so we're cheering for that, but Gus Partenza is dead. (CONTINUED )
His photo 80A. 173 appears behind her.

He was...everyone who knew him loved him. Even more than that, they liked him. It's hard to report the news when you're torn between excitement and sadness. I can't even imagine how they feel on the Messiah.
The astronauts are floating silently in the living quarte Monash is lying on the table, Baker works on his eyes with the med kit. It's painful. Tanner speaks quietly to Baker
Bad?  81.
Her look says it all. Tanner goes back to checking Simon. Partenza begins to cry softly.
Robin watches in silence.
The crowd

They're going to set off the bombs in thirteen minutes, well, less than thirteen now. (beat, she's reflecting) We're supposed to see a large increase in the comet's brightness as dust from the explosion is hit by the rays of the sun.
watches Jenny on MSNBC.

(she's looking off camera) Do we know if that's going to be visible to the naked eye or only on telescopes? ... We don't know. We do? Oh... naked eye. You'll see the brightness. We will, we'll see it together.
On the monitors we see images from around the Messiah.
Prepare to remove safeties and fire.
Safeties removed...
After the death of Dr. Gus Partenza and with Oren Monash injured, (MORE) (CONTINUED )
Spurgeon Tanner is now in command of the mission.

The Biedermans and Hotchners are still watching together. The comet as seen from the Messiah fills the screen. JENNY (CONT’D) Okay, this is what's coming next: the radiation burst is going to wipe out the transmission from the Messiah, just for a minute, maybe a little longer, so don't panic when the picture goes out. (CONTINUED )
Tanner, Baker and Tulchinsky are now up front.
Weapons armed. Tanner looks over at Partenza's helmet cam, only space in and out of heavy static.
We're detonating the bombs now, Gus.
...okay... He's very distant. None of them know what to say. A beat.
Unlock firing switches. Tanner and Baker unlock switch guards, exposing red "fire switches, side by side in the console.
Three... two... one... NOW.
Light shoots from the MOLE holes, then BLINDING WHITE.
The screen fills with static. Tanner's breaking up.
Weapons detonation... confirmed... 10:04, Zulu ...time, 24 Augu...,
Debris is hurled from the comet. SLAMS into the Messiah, shuts down the electrical system. FLIPS them sideways, BURSTING lights and a stern cargo WINDOW. ALARMS sound.

Decompression in area six! Tulchinsky leaps up out of his chair, pulls himself along the blender that's now the Messiah's interior, SLAMS agai pipes, floors, ceilings. THROWS himself against the cargo hatch door, trying to close it and not be sucked out.  183 184 185 186 187 83.
The static is beginning to clear.

Now we're just waiting for the picture to come back. This is hard. Twenty seconds. Slowly, the view of the comet from the Messiah returns. The comet's surrounded with debris, breaking into two pieces, one five times larger than the other. A huge CHEE erupts, the staff CLAPS, CRIES, they hug each other. Beth holds her daughter Caitlin.
What happened, Mommy?
It's Times Square on V-J Day, bedlam, joy.
Tulchinsky struggles the last few inches, gets the suckin hatch door closed, the wheel turned. Smoke, wires exposed Simon extinguishes a small fire. Baker looks to Partenza's helmet cam, only STATIC.
They watch the set, the dust, the two comets in space.

Messiah, this is Houston... Messiah can you respond... Everyone is elated, hugging, except for Leo. Sarah holds him, tears running down her face, but he's still watching the TV, worried. Slowly, she realizes.
-Leo...? But he doesn't answer, something's wrong. 183 184 185 186 187  84-85.

The room's crammed full of electronic gear, computers. Th President, Entrekin, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs SCOTT, other aides and advisors. No one says a word. All are turned toward Bekey, a phone to his ear. Waiting.

(into phone) ...I’m still here Listens for a long beat. Then hangs up, slowly turns to the President. He doesn't have to say it, they all know. The President stares at his feet, the weight of his job too great today. Then finally, quietly:
Your people ready, Morton? (Entrekin nods) General?
Yes, sir. The President nods, heads for the brightly lit Oval Offic next door.
Champagne, smiles, relieved tears. The President appears on the monitors, his voice cutting through the celebratio
Good evening. He takes a long time to say the next thing. The staff quiets, turns to watch. The President's grim expression slowly sucking the joy from the room. (CONTINUED )
You know what just happened. There was one big.comet, and now there are two. And they're both headed to earth.
We MOVE SLOWLY through the faces, then onto the long wall of monitors; every station carrying the speech.

Let's call the big one Wolf and the smaller piece, Biederman. Wolf is six miles wide, Biederman a mile and a half. Separately or together, they are capable of destroying life as we know it. Wwe have lost communication with the Messiah spacecraft although we continue to track it visually. It left the comet under power and has made course corrections under power. The ship is coming home. We don't know how many are alive. We don't know their condition. He takes a moment. All stare, the words sinking in.

Now we have to make some decisions together. What do we do? You have a choice, we have a choice right now. Ever since the comet was discovered, we've been hoping and working for the best, but we've also been planning for the worst. Our strategy has been two-fold. First, our Strategic Missile Command is preparing to coordinate with the Russians a massive strike of Titan missiles to intercept the incoming comets. If we can deflect these comets only two degrees they will bounce harmlessly off of our atmosphere and head out into space...
They watch the speech. Sarah clinging to Leo.
Unfortunately, the Titans cannot be launched until the comets are (MORE) (CONTINUED )

only a few hours away and while we are confident the Missile attack will succeed, it is only prudent that we now take cautionary steps to insure the continuation of our way of life. To guarantee that there will be enough of us left to rebuild a new world in the unlikely event that the comets do strike the earth...  87.
The CAMERA moves in slowly on the President.

So, in the soft limestone of Missouri, we've been preparing a network of immense caves, and they're almost finished, and we can put a million people in them, and that million people can survive there, underground, for two years, until the air clears and the dust settles. The cave is more than a dormitory, it's our new Noah's Ark: we're storing seeds and seedlings, plants and animals, enough to start over. On August 10, we're going to hold a national lottery...
The faces of people watching; in Times Square, in Chicago Seattle, Houston and San Francisco.

A computer will randomly select eight hundred thousand Americans, to join the two hundred thousand scientists, doctors, engineers, teachers, soldiers and artists who have already been chosen. Other countries are preparing similar caves along whatever lines they feel are best to preserve their ways of life. This is ours.
Robin is watching alone.

Beginning tonight, and continuing until the crisis passes, I am declaring a state of Martial Law. The Armed Forces and the National Guard are working with local law enforcement. A national curfew begins at midnight tonight. Wherever you are, go home. Stay off the roads after sunset. Crimes against persons or property will be dealt with swiftly and harshly.  87A.

News stations around the nation are being faxed copies of the lottery procedure as we speak and they'll be broadcasting the details to you in a few moments... Worth takes off running for the fax, Ira following.  87B-87C.
The President takes a break and stops reading copy. He tries to unburden his heart.

I... wish... no, wishing is the wrong word right now. That's not what I mean. Look... I believe in God. A lot of you don't. At times like this, it would just be obscene to use faith as a weapon. But I still want to offer a prayer and I've been trying to find the right one. So let me offer this. It’1l pray for our survival, mine included, because I believe that God hears all prayers... but I also believe that sometimes His answer is No. May the Lord lift up His divine countenance upon you, and give you peace. We hear a murmur of AMEN from the people in the Oval Offi or wherever we see this, if on a monitor in MSNBC.
The Presidential Seal's on the monitors. Jenny's camera light CLICKS ON. She looks off, all formality gone.

Do we have the fax yet, Stuart? (Stuart shakes “no”) Worth and Ira reappear from the hall, running. Worth carries a sheet of paper overhead, rushes it to the ancho desk. Jenny reads it as the crowded studio waits, silent. JENNY (CONT’D) My God... Stuart, how old are you?
Jenny, in five, four...
Fifty-five... Her camera light blinks RED. She slowly turns to camera. (CONTINUED )
We now have the details of the national lottery. (reads) Those of you who have been pre- selected for the Ark will be notified within the next few minutes...
We MOVE ACROSS the stunned faces, watching Jenny.

For the rest, on the night of May 14, those who's social security numbers have been randomly selected by computer will be notified. All phone systems will be turned off for 72 hours beginning on May 13th. The only phones that ring will be those of the people selected...
Robin watches her daughter deliver the news on TV.

While some Americans over fifty years of age have been pre-selected for the Ark due to their expertise in a necessary field of study, no men and women over fifty in the general population will be included in the lottery...
Chloe gives Jason a look. I don't know about you, but I will survive.
The evacuation of those who have been selected for the Ark will take no longer than two days beginning on May 18th...
The phone RINGS. Everyone looks. It RINGS again.
...Hello...?
During this two day period, no unofficial travel will be permitted. (MORE) (CONTINUED )
Those selected will be taken by bus and train to the underground Ark site by military personnel... Ellen hangs up slowly, turns back to the room.
We've been pre-selected. All turn to Leo, they know why. Chuck leaps up, rushes for the front door.
Chuck...? Where're you going?
Our phone! They could be calling! And he's gone. They look among themselves, they all know the Hotchner phone isn't ringing across the street.

You are being notified now because there is still time to construct your own shelters in basements and backyard pools. Civil Defense teams have been formed in every town and city in America with a population over five thousand. They will distribute supplies and organize group shelters in underground parking facilities and other appropriate sites. Construction plans, equipment lists and locations for securing the necessary provisions along with information on how to grow your own food underground and how to purify water are now available free of charge on the Internet at WwW. FEMA.Com. Jenny stops reading. It's silent. She sets the fax down slowly, looks directly into camera.
That's all there is.  87F.
Monash strapped down, gauze covering his eyes, in pain. Tanner and Baker work on the radio, Tulchinsky at the Ori Simon pours over schematics, his arm now roughly splinted (CONTINUED )
The interior camera circuitry is shot. Andy, can we get back into the cargo bay to reroute the video junctions?
Starboard cargo porthole is blown. We could try to get in there with the EVA's but there's not much left in the life support packs.
We should be able to raise Houston on the low band when we get closer.
The Orion still functioning?
System check was okay, but I don't know about the radiation shielding.
So, if we fire it up, we beat the comet back to earth, but we may start glowing in the dark. Anybody? A silent beat, then from the corner, hoarsely --
Let's go home...
The Orion fires against the backplate, the Messiah picks up tremendous speed, leaves the comets behind.
David Letterman on stage, talking to his audience.

The comets are such great set-ups for a joke, but the problem is that we're the punchline. So here's my last top ten list. Ten: be grateful to the crew of the Messiah for everything they tried to do. Nine: Make peace with your enemies. Eight: Be strong for the children. Seven: Try to help someone you don't know. Six: Don't get crazy. (MORE) (CONTINUED )
Five: Don't be selfish. Four: Love your friends and family. Three: Love your friends and family. Two: Love your friends and family. One: Love your friends and family... Slowly, he walks off stage.

I have to say it's liberating knowing that I won't be called. I don't think I've ever been happier. I've even stopped smoking.

Within a week, the skies will be dark with dust from the impact and they will stay dark for two years. All plant life will be dead within four weeks, animal life within a few months.
The President continues, looks directly into camera.
Good luck.  257

The truck's turning around to head west. Everyone's jumpi back on frantically, except Leo who's standing in the roa The last few people hop on or are dragged up by others. T truck completes its turn. A large HISPANIC MAN leans out, offers Leo his hand.
Come on...! But Leo doesn't move. The people in the back of the truck stare at him. The truck barrels off west. Leo turns, begins to run east, toward the lightening horizon.

Simon's under the radio panel, working with his one good hand on a jumble of wires. Other wires now criss-cross the ceiling of the cabin in a crazy tennis racket grid of colors. Through the cracked windshield, the Earth.
Try that...
I'm getting something.
A single GUY sits in the crammed comm room, watching MSNB on a small set. Hears a SCRATCHY sound. Sits up. What?
Houston...is...Messiah. Houston, this... the Messiah...
Messiah, this is Houston, go ahead... Another man sticks his head in from the hallway.
Get Hefter, quick!
The astronauts let off a WHOOP, elated to be back on line
Nice of you to call Messiah, we were starting to wonder what the hell you were doing up there. Tanner motions for everyone to shut up. (CONTINUED )
Admiring the view, Houston.
Fish, that you?
Yep. Sorry we don't have time to talk Houston, we need the arming codes for the last four nukes.
What the hell for?
Mitch, we can do, or we can teach, what's your pleasure?
More and m
ore NASA folks jam into the room.
Get the arming codes! Get the goddamn codes!

Worth's running a mini meeting, it's somber, quiet, a circle. Beer and wine containers litter the table, everyo smokes. A few younger, staffers, Jenny, Eric, Beth with Caitlin, Ira, Tim, Bobby, Marianne.

We have one helicopter. It holds seven people. We can ferry six people to high ground in West Virginia and take Jenny to the ark. They look around, there are thirteen of them, not countin Jenny and Eric. They aren't all going to make it. Worth reaches behind him for coffee stirrers, counts out thirte breaks the ends off six. Everyone watches, it's very quie
Short sticks go.
I always thought it was, "women and children first.”

If you pick short, you can give up your seat. He offers his hand slowly around the room. Each person picks a straw. One at a time. Marianne's first, a long straw. A short one for the next man, he smiles. Bobby picks a long one. Ira, long. Short. Long. Tim, short. Long. Long. A woman begins to cry. Short. Eric has to choose. He looks to Jenny. He chooses a straw. Short. He takes Jenny's hand. Now, it's just Beth and worth. Two sticks. One long and one short. Beth looks at Worth, at Caitlin beside her. Takes a deep breath. Picks one. It's long. Worth opens his hand, the one remaining stick, short. There's a long silent beat.
Oh my God, Beth... What are you going to do?
There's always the road. I'll be all right.
(making the best of a worst situation) Well...I...I’m going to learn French. (CONTINUED )
Beth gets up and leaves. They all watch her go.
All right, let's get moving!
Wolf and Biederman tumble towards Earth.  260
Tanner, Baker and Tulchinsky are working on the last bomb Parts float around, tools. Simon's at the comm board. Monash is strapped to his seat.
The code transfer is going too slow, I can't get a clear signal.
They'll come or they won't, worrying about it won't help. Tanner struggles to detach the nuke from its cumbersome MOLE mounting capsule. He's whistling. Baker looks down at him. Among the others.
Are you whistling?
Yep... Baker grins, shakes his head.
You're happy aren't you, Fish...? Tanner doesn't answer for moment, then:

During the middle ages, a Swedish Knight, returning home from the crusades, got caught by the plague. The Angel of Death came to take him away, he was on a beach and there was no place to hide. Baker and Simon trade looks, here he goes again.

Death said, "It's time to go." The Knight took a look at him and said, "I've heard you're a chess player." Death said, "That's true." The Knight said, "Death, why don't we play a game of chess? As long as I hold you off, you don't claim my soul. And if I win, I live forever." Death smiled and said, "Let's play." (CONTINUED )
Tanner gets the nuke out, takes it to the table where Simon's fashioned straps out of scrap to hold the nukes i place.

The Knight held him off for a long time, until one day, the Knight stopped in a church for confession. And in the dark of that confessional, he told the priest about the chess game, and how Death had overlooked a move, and how he, the Knight, was just one jump away from a checkmate. And the priest pulled back the screen, and it was Death himself. The Knight had given away his game. Everyone's listening now, lost in their own emotions.

There was no chance to recover. He was going to lose. The Knight went outside, and he looked at his hands, and he could see the blood still flowing in his veins, and he said, "There it is, I'm still alive, and I, Antonius Block - that was his name - I, Antonius Block, am playing Chess with Death!" Tanner finishes screwing the final nuke in place, slips o a control lead, the nukes LED's BLINK on. He smiles.
It's been a hell of game.

A freeway sign: "RICHMOND BEACHES 6 MILES." The CAMERA BOOMS DOWN to find bumper to bumper traffic on both sides of the road heading west. Cars are HONKING, RADIOS are on tempers FLARE. News CHOPPERS overhead. WE MOVE DOWN TO FIND Leo, on a bike heading the opposite direction -- east, into town.

Sarah and her family in the red Astro Minivan, stuck in horrible traffic. Sarah sneaks a look up front, ON THE DIGITAL SPEEDOMETER: 4 miles an hour. Chuck sees his daughter looking. They're in trouble. And they know it.
(CONTINUED )
The COMETS' POV: Earth fills the horizon.

The street's deserted, weeds choke lawns, trash is piled up everywhere, broken windows, doors ripped off hinges. Leo pedals up the street, hard. Passes abandoned cars, dogs roaming free eating garbage. Dumps the bike on Sarah's dead lawn, rushes into --
The front door bars have been pried off, wood hanging fro the jam. It's oddly quiet, family photos missing, leaves blowing around, the place has been looted. (CONTINUED )
Sarah! Sarah...! No answer, he's near panic.
A metal toolshed door RATTLES in the breeze. A front door SLAPS back and forth.
Sarah...! A cat scoots across the street. A car wreck sits under the streetlight. He checks both cars for keys, nothing. Runs along the houses, all deserted.- Nobody.
Hello! Hello...! Nothing. Just the empty street.

It's getting creepy now, Leo's spooked. He runs up to his own garage, pulls the partially destroyed garage door up. The garage has been looted, too. Old toys strewn around, dolls, baby clothing. But sitting against the wall, still chained in place. His Dad's dirt bike, its heavy duty chain and massive lock still in there, showing the eviden of several attempts to break it. Leo digs among the scattered paint cans. Finds the right one. The keys still in their hiding place. Unlocks it. Climbs on, turns it over with a ROAR. FLIES down the driveway and out into the street, barely hanging on.
The astronauts watch Biederman entering the atmosphere. (CONTINUED )
We ready? Everyone's strapped in, Tanner and Baker up front with Simon. Tulchinsky and Monash next to the nukes. All nod.
Houston, this is Messiah. We're ready to begin our run. Our families there yet?
They're on their way, Messiah. Good luck. Kenny takes the yoke, begins a turn.
Disengage autopath. Here we go...

The Messiah sling shots around the Earth, heading for the massive Wolf. We SWING BACK TO Biederman's view of the earth as it approaches the atmosphere and begins to heat up. SCREAMS past a satellite, starts to glow.
Leo ROARS along the shoulder, up and down the grass embankments trying to miss abandoned cars. Surfing the sea of slow moving traffic. Searching for the Astrovan.
Jenny and Eric are running through the building. They have to cross the studio. Jenny runs to her desk.
What are you doing? (CONTINUED )
I have to get something. She grabs the envelope her Father gave her.
Jenny! Let's go! She runs with him. They pass the day care center. There are Beth and Caitlin, playing. Jenny stops.
(surprised) Beth!
Jenny! He's already at the door to the roof. The others are pushing past him. When the door opens we can hear the noise of the helicopter on the roof.
Jenny! We have to go!

The roads were so crowded, it was obvious that we weren't going to make it. If the wave is going to come, I thought, well, she likes it here. It's the fifteenth floor who knows, maybe we'll be alright.
Caitlin. Come here. Caitlin comes to her. Jenny picks her up.
Say goodbye to Jenny, Caitlin.
Jenny! There's no time left!
Let' s go.
Where? Jenny starts running with Caitlin. Caitlin drops her doll
Let's go. They all start running up the stairs together.  124B.
They come to the roof. A helicopter is waiting for them, and another chopper has just left. The sky is filled with helicopters and small planes, all heading west.
We're going to make it, we're going to make it, let's go, let's go, now, now, now...
Where are you going with my Caitlin? Jenny seems to have an aura around her, something is hold her back from the fear and tension that everyone else is showing on their faces. She's actually calm.
You're taking Caitlin and you're taking my seat.
why? A few people are already in the chopper.
Get inside! Beth rushes in.
Caitlin, I love you. Jenny hands Caitlin to her mother. Eric is about to get on.
What are you doing? The Pilot looks doubtfully at the number of people he's supposed to carry.
That's too many.
We can make it.
I'm not going. Goodbye, Eric.
What? (CONTINUED )
Thank you, thank you, thank you.
We gotta go! And he starts to lift off.
No!
Goodbye, Eric. Eric is holding Jenny's hand as the helicopter rises.
But I love you. Jenny hears this, and smiles. She kisses his hand.
Next time!
Next time! And then their hands separate, and the helicopter flies off the roof, and joins the swarm of planes going west.

We are looking east on the freeway, at the miles of cars, filling both sides of the road and all heading west. They are stopped, or moving at a mile an hour. We are on the westbound lanes, looking at the back of a sign over the freeway. We cross to the eastbound lane and a sign saying BEACHES... We continue across the highway and over the embankment to an access road, where one car heading towards the water. We find the driver: Jenny. (CONTINUED )

Leo on his motorbike, wearing a helmet, through the traff Cars everywhere, impossible to get through. An Astrovan... he goes up to it: the wrong family. Another Astrovan... the wrong people. Leo drives up onto the center median. Other motorcyclists are using the same road. HE PASSES THE HOTCHNER FAMILY. Vicky sees him.
Vicky sees Leo.
Look... Sarah... Look... Sarah and Chuck see Leo.
Leo! She throws herself over her Father to hit the horn. But all the cars are honking.
Leo is ahead of the Hotchners.
She gets out of the car and climbs up on the roof.
Leo doesn't hear her.

text: A girl on a van.
He stops. He turns around. He sees Sarah. She is off the van, and running to him through the stoppe traffic. He rides back to her. (CONTINUED )
They kiss. Vicky, carrying the Baby, and Chuck, are out of the van, coming to them.
You don't have any time, you have to go now.
Here... She gives Sarah the Baby.
Mom...
Make a life.
I'll take care of them, I promise...
I know you will. Go, please go... Sarah nods, crying. Leaps on the back of his bike.

We love you, we always loved you, now get out of here, now, now, now. Go! Leo and Sarah, holding the Baby, get on the motorbike, an get out of there as fast as they can, leaving Chuck and Vicky on the road.
The comet's POV, low in the atmosphere, streaking over th earth.
Chuck and Vicky Hotchner lean against their stopped van. He has his arm around her. She lets him hold her. He looks up... Everyone is looking up, she looks up... there's the comet.
Biederman. People get out of their cars, slowly. WE BOOM UP, to see miles of jammed road, all traffic has stopped as a millio people make peace with the end of their lives. 276 277
Leo and Sarah ROAR off the freeway, FLY past an endless line of cars crawling slowly into the green hills. Sarah sees the comet first.
Oh no... Streaking overhead. Leo yells over the NOISE of the bike.
Fifteen minutes after it hits we'll feel the shock wave! Hold on...! He LAYS on the gas, Sarah holding onto Leo and the baby for dear life.

Stuart walks calmly along the street in a suit and tie. People run past, cars JAMMED bumper to bumper in the stre HONKING, trying desperately to get out of the city. But Stuart's calm, relaxed. Finds a -- Curbside Starbucks coffee cart, umbrella, it's deserted. Makes himself a cup of espresso. The portable TV on the cart now only STATIC. Grabs a New York Times from an abandoned news stand. The NY tabloids hanging from it's sides scream "COMET TO CITY: DROP DEAD!" And "THE FAT LADY SINGS!", the Times simply states, "Wolf, Biederman Impact Imminent" and in smaller type, "Scientists Disagre On Extent Of Destruction". He walks through the chaos and out into Washington Square among the pigeons. Sits on the steps near the Arch, sets his coffee to one side, lights a cigarette, opens his pap

The comet is coming to ground. Forest and fields on shore IGNITE, the ocean BOILS as the comet SPLASHES into the se a few miles off the coast. The white hot tip of the comet breaks the surface. The hole in the ocean begins to spread. Merges with the earth and FROM ABOVE, the circle of the impact spreads. On shore, the earth RIPPLES away in harmony with the water. And then the shock wave catches up with the fires, BLOWIN them out as it KNOCKS the forests flat. (CONTINUED )

Farms and towns are thrown into the air, then roads and c SHOCKED into vapor by the impact. The ocean wave begins t form, TOWERING above. WE'RE MOVING fast... Down the East Coast ... Faster than the speed of sound... Cities COLLAPSE, forests, bridges. Everything in its path.

Jenny drives down the deserted country road, heading east when SUDDENLY the ground RIPPLES towards her, as if the highway were a rug and God was shaking out the dust. Tree FALL, telephone poles SNAP. The car FLIES over the sudden three foot speed bump. SLAMS back to the road, with a metal GRINDING THUMP, Jenny keeps going.
Leo and Sarah. The RIPPLING earth catches up to them from behind, moving fast. Sarah sees, SCREAMS to Leo.
Oh God...! It catches them. The motorcycle JUMPS, bounces up over the rolling ground. They land HARD, Leo struggles to keep the bike upright, Sarah clutching the bundled Baby.
The wave is a thousand feet high and moves across the oce in a line that stretches past the horizon. OIL RIGS are simply swallowed whole.

Jenny arrives at the beach colony, with beautiful weather old ramshackle cottages behind fences on the dunes. She has the photographs that Jason gave her at MSNBC. She has found the cottage in the background. Ahead of her, through a break in the houses, a path to th sea. A dog barks. The birds wheel overhead. She walks to the sand. She takes off her shoes. She's carrying a bag and she flings it away. No more than a hundred or so people are on the beach, families, old people, children, and dogs. A little girl h a cockatiel in a birdcage. She lets it go. The bird flies away. There's a boy in a wheelchair. His parents set him on the sand, near the water's edge. Couples are kissing, families are hugging each other. A man alone plays frisbe with his black lab. (CONTINUED)
Someone is playing the guitar. There's Jason, standing alone, looking out at the sea. He comes to her.
Jenny...
When I was eleven, I stole money from your wallet.
When you were a baby, I dropped you on your head.

When you came to the studio, and you showed me the pictures, I lied when I told you that I didn't remember. I was so mad at you, because I remembered everything. I remember the day, it was a perfect happy day. We were right over here... We were all alone on the beach, and Mom was really upset because she'd left her tripod in the house. I'm here because I wanted you to know. They walk to the water's edge.
Thank you. I miss her, too. Jenny stares at her Father.
I wish I could make up all that lost time for you.

(no irony, she means this) We have the rest of our lives. And then a terrible sound, not the wave, something else: The sky is filled with SQUAWKING sea birds flying inland, dense cloud of gulls, terns, and pelicans. Everyone on th beach begins to join hands in a line at the water's edge, gently, without the need to talk. The DOGS run away from them, away from the water. And then the sea before them is SUCKED away in a massive tide, exposing fish and an old wreck. Something foams on horizon. Here it comes. Imagine the Santa Monica mountain rolling toward you, faster than the speed of sound. (CONTINUED )
Jenny grabs her father.
Daddeeee! Father holds daughter. The sound is DEAFENING. And they'r gone.
(CONTINUED )

The wave sweeps down the freeway, gathering thousands of cars in its foam. The Hotchners wait, holding each other. Vicky looks up at her husband, smiles. And they disappear as the tidal wave sucks up fifty thousand cars.
Two F-16's SCREAM into view, towards the Manhattan skylin They close in on the STATUE OF LIBERTY. They veer off in opposite directions as the GIANT WAVE enters frame and th sky starts to darken.
The wave sweeps over lower Manhattan, around and between and over the twin towers of the World Trade Center.
It tears through Soho.
From Times Square, you can see it coming up Broadway and Seventh Avenue.
The rushing crowds around Stuart, stop. Climb out of thei cars, look eastward. A tremendous NOISE. Stuart looks up from his paper. Takes a final deep drag of his cigarette, and he's gone.
Looking up at the Chrysler building we see an ocean liner tossed by the wave into the skyscraper's top floors.
FROM ABOVE: looking down at the Empire State Building as the wave surges through mid-town.
FROM BELOW: As the Statue of Liberty floats face down abo the drowned city. 291 291 292
293 294 FROM THE SURFACE OF THE WATER: the wave has passed, leavi one tower of the World Trade Center leaning against the other, water draining from the shattered windows.

Leo and Sarah ROAR over a hill to see a mountain road ris above, traffic JAMMED all the way up. Sedans have tried t negotiate the shoulder and gotten stuck. There's nowhere go. Leo idles for a moment. Looks around desperately, Steve McQueen in The Great Escape. Behind them, in the fa distance, something is COMING. He REVS the engine.

Hold on! FLIES off into the brush, looking for a trail, anything. The bushes and branches SLAP at their faces, SCRATCH and TEAR. A deer trail. Not much but they'll take it. It's steep, not meant for motorcycles. The wrong move and they'll FLY off into the woods. Dirt SAILS off the tires as they SKID and SLAM over branches and decomposing leaves. They come around a bend, a huge TREE down ahead. Leo brak to try to stop, but the bike SKIDS underneath them. They down. Leo and Sarah falling, SLIDING behind it. (CONTINUED )
The cycle SMASHES into the tree, SLAMS up and over it ina twisting somersault of metal and paint. And suddenly, it's silent. Leo sits up, clothes torn, covered in mud and dirt. Crawls back to Sarah.
Sarah...? Sarah...?! She's a few feet behind him, face scrapped, more concerne about the baby still strapped to her chest.
I think he's okay... CRYING like hell, but alright. Leo pulls her up.
We have to keep going, can you run? She nods. He drags her behind him over the tree, the bike a mangled mess, the back wheel still spinning.
It covers the countryside, the crest of the beast eating everything in its way, devouring entire states.
Leo and Sarah running. People behind them, above them.
It reaches the base of the hills. An immense force, the water piling up on the mountain as easily as water ina bathtub surges over the side if you give it a push.

The United States coastline has changed. Cape Cod is gone New York City and Long Island. No Chesapeake Bay. No Carolinas or Florida. The ocean reaches inland from the White Mountains of New Hampshire to the Poconos, to the B Ridge Mountains and the Appalachians.
The bombs are strapped to the cabin table, their LEDs blinking 0:00:20. Ready to be started.
We're at perigee. Wolf contact in three minutes, forty-five seconds. Wolf dead ahead, heading for earth. (CONTINUED )
We'll never be closer to home then we are right now. They watch the earth below them.
Messiah, we've got some people down here who want to talk to you...

Leo and Sarah CRASH out of the woods onto the road, out o breath. HEAR the thing behind them. Look back -- White foam, DEAFENING noise, planes overhead. People run out of the forest, the water rising behind them, ROARING up out of the woods. The Atlantic Ocean now two hundred miles west of where it was this morning.
The families of the astronauts, monitors set up in front of them, Simon's scratchy image. His fiancee, Wendy, crying.
Wendy, if you let this ruin your life, I'm going to come back to haunt you.
Please, come back and haunt me.
It's Baker's turn, her husband and two daughters.
Take care of Daddy for me, okay? (the little girls nod) David, you know what I want to say.
I know.
Next up is Tulchinsky. He starts in English, switches to Russian and then a SIMULTANEOUS TRANSLATOR takes over.
I was in love with three women in my life. You know who you are. (in Russian, translated) I was stupid, I couldn't decide. (MORE) (CONTINUED )
Each of you is beautiful and unique and I didn't want to give that up. But I loved you, don't ever doubt that, I loved you all...
Leo and Sarah are trying to make it to higher ground but the wave CRESTS over the road. CATCHES them.
Sarah!
Leo! LIFTS them up as they're carried by the water, TURNED and TOSSED, ROLLED and BUMPED together.
Wolf looms very large, dead ahead. Tulchinsky helps Monas get in place for the camera. Baker's counting down.
Wolf contact in two minutes, thirty seconds. Hefter's face appears in the Houston monitor, distressed.
Oren, Mariette was up at your folks place in Utah, we sent a plane for her, but she isn't here yet. The other's watch Monash's face. The clock's down to 2:14
And Fish, your sons are both on active duty, we couldn't get them back here in time. I'm sorry. We tried. Spurgeon, I was wrong. You were the best man for the job. Tanner nods, not surprised.
Mitch? I want to say good-bye to Mary. I want to tell her I love her, and that, ever since we've been apart, every day, I think about her. (then) I'm coming home, Mary. (CONTINUED )
Coming up on target 126 miles, RDOT .3, 1 degree X, 15 degrees Yous Tanner looks away from the monitor, takes the controls.
115 miles, .3, 2 degrees X, 13 Yous
Wolf rolls slowly, the vent clearly ahead of them. The Messiah heads into the mass of coma and rocks.
Mariette, with the baby, runs into the building, military escorts struggling to keep up.
Wait...oh god...wait...!
The comet is nearing the earth's atmosphere.
They're BANGING around, the worst, downhill four-wheel drive off road experience you can imagine. Tanner tries to hold it on target.
76 miles. Wolf impact in forty- five seconds...
Oren?... Oren, are you there?! Monash turns to his wife's voice. Her picture breaking up as they FIGHT their way through the dense coma.
Mariette? I'm here, I can hear you.
The terrifyingly jumpy interior of the ship and Monash on the static filled monitor. Mariette holds up their child.
Baby... This is your father. (CONTINUED )
Mariette!
His name is Oren, I named him after you. OREN JR. Dadda!
Oren. Oren Jr. holds up to the camera a rocket toy he has been clutching. (CONTINUED )
We see the image of the baby and the rocket on the Messia monitor.
What happened? OREN JR. Look!
(helping out Monash) He's holding up a little rocket.
Oh, what a powerful rocket you have. The Baby coos and giggles.
He's laughing.
I can hear him. Mariette...
In 40 miles...25 seconds... She keeps counting. Tanner yells back to Tulchinsky.
Prepare to synchronize the nukes.
...I'm hugging you both right now... I'm holding you...
We're holding you! Tulchinsky has a makeshift button, wires run from it to the nukes. 0:00:20 frozen on their LEDs.
Tulchinsky hits the button and the nukes begin to count down in perfect unison...19...18...
It's been a pleasure serving with you, Commander. Tanner doesn't take his eyes off the vent. (CONTINUED )
The honor's all mine, Andy...
We love you, Oren...

Mariette's crying, hell, everybody's crying. Monash's face, his hand touching the camera. And then, he's gone. The monitor suddenly filled with STATIC. The baby leans forward trying to touch the screen, mystified.
Wolf begins heating up as the Messiah ROARS into the vent swallowed whole: Nothing. Didn't it work? And then, a BLINDING light SHOOT out... and BOOM. Everything goes WHITE.
Leo and Sarah sit up in the middle of the flooded road. The water draining away as the wave recedes. Sarah still has the CRYING baby in her arms.

...look... THE SKY: overhead, far away, Wolf and a brilliant light followed by a massive rolling wave of THUNDER that shakes the earth. They walk to the edge of the road, look out over the valley, the ocean slowly receding below.

It's going away. And then all the pieces from the explosion begin HITTING the atmosphere. The greatest meteor shower in history, FIREWORKS in the day brighter than at night. The entire sky filled with color and light, STREAKING, BURNING. Leo can't speak. Sarah holds Leo, the baby. The baby stares at the sky, the ocean, mesmerized. Begins to LAUGH...
